item.description: At Olin, I’m a member of Olin Electric Motorsports, our Formula SAE electric race car team. I work on firmware, mostly for high voltage power distribution and network management. navigate down to learn more ðŸ”½ High Voltage Power Distribution I worked on the firmware for the battery management system and the battery contactor controller. I designed the firmware to be robust and readable. I believe that safety-critical code should be easy to understand and as simple as possible.
Here are some projects I’ve worked on… CAN Bootloader MKV BMS Contactor Control Kalman Filter SoC Estimation

CAN Bootloader A bootloader that can reprogram chips using CAN. Github link. navigate down to learn more ðŸ”½ Historically, whenever we wanted to update the firmware on our circuit boards, we had to use an in-system programming (ISP) dongle and plug into each board manually. This often meant opening up enclosure, and required us to have a large programming header on each board, adding height and exposed copper. As a personal project, I developed a bootloader for the ATmega16m1, the microcontroller we use on the team, that allows us to update the firmware of any ECU on our CAN bus.

MKV BMS A battery management system for a 400V EV battery. Code repository. Documentation. navigate down to learn more ðŸ”½ For the Olin Electric Motorsports MKV vehicle, we had a 400V battery pack built with 864 18650 lithium batteries. In order to ensure safe operation, we built a custom BMS. A few of my teammates worked on the electrical systems and PCBs, and I wrote the firmware. The BMS core uses isoSPI to communicate with peripheral boards, each containing two LTC6811 battery management integrated chips.
